title: Brooklyn judge who granted stay presides over naturalization
text:
Brooklyn judge who issued stay of travel ban conducts naturalization ceremony, calls on new citizens to be ‘active participants' Brooklyn judge who granted stay presides over naturalization Judge Ann Donnelly happened to be presiding over Tuesday's naturalization ceremonies. (New York Daily News) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   5:05 PM 
The Brooklyn federal judge who temporarily halted President Trump's immigration ban urged newly sworn American citizens on Tuesday to be “active participants" in their country's affairs. 
Three days after Judge Ann Donnelly granted an emergency stay blocking the removal of individuals legally authorized to enter from countries like Iraq, Somalia and Syria, the judge happened to be presiding over the day's naturalization ceremonies. 
It was a duty Donnelly called the "happiest and nicest things we judges do." 
She made no mention of the blockbuster Saturday evening ruling in the case, which has been reassigned. Protesters rally in NYC against Trump's travel ban 
But the judge discussed immigration, citizenship and referred to former President Barack Obama's farewell letter where the outgoing President talked about the "joyous work of citizenship." 
Donnelly, a state court judge and longtime Manhattan prosecutor before joining the federal bench, asked the approximately 100 new citizens to vote, serve on juries, “speak out on issues of importance to you" and also "dream big." 
Donnelly pointed to the ceremonial courtroom's Depression-era mural, which shows immigrants hard at work building railroads, farming and doing other heavy labor. A woman holds a sign acknowledging a stay affecting immigrants trying to reach the United States issued late Saturday by Donnelly amid protests over the weekend. (Kathy Willens/AP) 
Judge hailed for blocking Trump immigration ban 
Many people in the courthouse were either immigrants or descendants of immigrants, Donnelly noted, adding, "We celebrate this with all you." 
The United States was at its best when focusing on "common history and experiences," not on differences, she said. President Trump signs an executive order Monday aimed at significantly cutting regulations.The judge issued a stay of part of his earlier order on immigration. (Pablo Martinez Monsivais/AP) 
"I welcome you all as fellow citizens," the judge said before leaving. 
Donnelly ruled on the petition because she was the weekend duty judge. The case and other related actions have been randomly reassigned to Judge Carol Bagley Amon. 
Protesters rally in lower Manhattan against Trump’s travel ban 
Boris Denadic, 35, was one of the newly minted citizens who heard Donnelly. 
Denadic said he felt happy to call himself an American citizen. He said he spent more than one third of his life in the United States "so I feel like I belong here." Join the Conversation:
